children.subject: There are two other candidates, but the times haven't been scheduled yet. I'll ask if they can be shared more, I don't think there should be any objections.
Who are the two other candidates? Do they have any connection to UC Berkeley?
I'll ask about that too. But 1 of them for sure has connections, I don't know about the other.
That all happened today? These would be cool to know about.

history.content: The other two candidates are Gireeja Ranade and Peter-Michael Osera. I would personally contact Andrew Huang (andrew.huang@berkeley.edu) if you have interest in attending the interviews. I think the mock classes are open to everyone, but I believe the meeting with undergrads is supposed to involve fewer undergrads for a more personal meeting with the candidates. =================== Hi, Andrew here. Josh's events were scheduled/announced last minute. I received notification of them the night before. The two other candidates have events next week, and you can check the pinned post (@132) for more info. :)

The other two candidates are Gireeja Ranade and Peter-Michael Osera. I would personally contact Andrew Huang (andrew.huang@berkeley.edu) if you have interest in attending the interviews. I think the mock classes are open to everyone, but I believe the meeting with undergrads is supposed to involve fewer undergrads for a more personal meeting with the candidates. =================== Hi, Andrew here. Josh's events were scheduled/announced last minute. I received notification of them the night before. The two other candidates have events next week, and you can check the pinned post for more info. :)

The other two candidates are Gireeja Ranade and Peter-Michael Osera. I would personally contact Andrew Huang (andrew.huang@berkeley.edu) if you have interest in attending the interviews.

I think the mock classes are open to everyone, but I believe the meeting with undergrads is supposed to involve fewer undergrads for a more personal meeting with the candidates.

children.subject:
Having only people who do well in CS classes or take super hard ones like CS164 with Hilfie evaluate the candidates is not representative.

Average students would provide a much different perspective that's just as valid.

If they want a more personal meeting, maybe they could have one session for just the TAs.

And a second, less personal session for all the other undergrads who are interested in speaking with the candidates.

That's a good compromise so there's a personal meeting as well as a second meeting so people won't feel left out because they're not TAs.
Several CS and EECS student organizations were invited, in addition to the TAs of several classes.

So basically you have to be part of an in-group to be invited? I'm not part of an in-group so I wouldn't have been even given a chance to know about the interviews had this not been posted here. I would have loved to speak to Josh Hug and learn more about him. Really disappointing.

So far I know it was TAs / HKN / UPE / CSUA and a couple other CS groups -- I'm not sure how far those groups were supposed to pass down announcements.

I asked Dan today and he said once the dates are set for the other 2 candidates it should be good to share the info. The dates should be finalized soon so hopefully you'll hear something. Or if you don't ping me. :)

I do agree it'd be nice to have more people involved. :)

On the thing about it being an in-group -- I think it was more to keep the size manageable, but not meant to exclude people. In my experience no one is trying to be super selective about who's involved, more just who has gradually been involved in these things before. If you're interested, you might try reaching out to Dan, or PNH or Scott Shenker.

Also in terms of culture and inclusivity and making others involved, I think these would be good things to bring up at the CS town hall whenever it happens.
(I also didn't see that the names were posted earlier...so I guess there's that! That's all i know, at least right now.)

I didn't mean to imply anything like you need to be part of a group to attend the interviews. I think it's open to all undergraduates. In fact, at the first undergrad meeting with Josh, there were several undergrads who were not TAs or part of clubs (like one undergrad was a student currently taking 61B).

To clarify, I didn't mean that the meetings are exclusive. I meant that they are small, so if you are interested, contact Andrew.

The 61B undergrad is taking 61B with Josh Hug so maybe that's where s/he heard it from? Maybe the other undergrads heard it from friends who were TAs or part of the clubs? I don't know where else they would have heard about it because I didn't see any announcements about it.

I didn't think you were implying that you don't have to be part of a group to attend the interviews. If other undergrads heard about it, sure no one would stop them from attending. It's just that only people who were part of those groups (TAs and CS groups) were told about it.

I think it is important to have views from a diverse spectrum of the CS community. Not just TAs or CS group members. Or friends of TAs or CS group members. People from varying social backgrounds will provide valuable insight into the teaching philosophy that would best serve the community at large.

I think it's a huge mistake just to notify a small cross-section of the CS community. It would be best to let other people know, maybe through the EECS/CS mailing lists and EECS website?
Lab assistants for CS 10 definitely heard about it. I agree with the sentiments of opening them up.

That's definitely true. To be honest, I think the whole process is a bit disorganized at the moment. I did see it announced in 164, but I only got an email from Prof. Garcia 4 minutes after the event had already started. So I also missed Josh's vision talk. :P

I think a future goal should definitely be to get these things better publicized and to solidify schedules so that people are more adequately notified. Haha.

In general, this is more transparent than last year -- though there are certainly lots of ways the process could be improves.  (Josh, John Denero and 1 other also interviewed last year(.

As far as the CS10 LA's. There are perhaps 2-3 that were sitting in at our (way overcrowded :P) meeting Monday when Dan mentioned it, though during the meeting his comments were more directed to letting people know than inviting everyone to everything. (Though he did wants the talks to be full, so I don't know exactly what he said. Tbh, I was probably half awake. #BadTA).

I'm definitely going to try to share the times / dates once they're solidified, though I will still ask for permission first.

I do want more transparency, in the dept and so please everyone let staff and faculty to know you'd like info to be shared and be involved in these things. (This also includes filling out the survey if you haven't.)

Transparency is definitely needed in the CS dept. I didn't even know people there were interviews last year, which I completely missed. Were those advertised to a select group too?

Michael, would you talk about the interviewing process for last year? What were Josh Hug, John DeNero, and the third candidate interviewing for? Who was the third candidate? Who was selected and why?

It was a smaller group than this year for sure and like this year, I don't think the intention was ever to be selective. Rather I think few people thought to invite more.

I need to sleep but I'll post a longer response tomorrow.
bump

Last year it wasn't really advertised.  It sort of happened and passed around by word-of-mouth.  I also heard about it very close to the actual date, so I don't think there was much time to actually plan.

Last year, there were essentially just the two candidates.  There was a third candidate at one point, but she (I think it was a woman) dropped out before any interviews (I don't know why).  We (undergrads) liked both candidates and gave positive feedback for both of them.  Ultimately, John was hired based on feedback from undergrads, graduate students, and faculty.  (That decision was made by other people and I don't know how it happened.)  Later Josh was also hired for a "Lecturer 18" job apparently.
What does 18 mean in Lecturer 18?

Ack, Piazza just deleted my post! >:(

Also, sorry for getting busy and forgetting to respond! My bad.

Rohin said basically what I would have. However, I will add that last year, like this year, there is only 1 official permanent position open. From what I understand strings were pulled and phone calls were made to create a second temporary position to get Josh, since we all liked him. 

(Tbh, I'm a bit sad that I won't have a chance to take a class from him!)

The 18, refers to the Contract code section for the UC System. There's a whole bunch of codes here:

http://ucnet.universityofcalifornia.edu/labor/bargaining-units/index.html

There's actually a whole section for GSI and related titles as well.

Basically, it's more like an "adjunct" faculty -- there's no tenure, no academic senate voting / participation, and your contracts are usually pretty short. (Sometimes only 1 semester, I think...)

The current open position is for a Lecturer PSOE which basically means there's the option to get tenure (SOE), and to be a part of the academic senate.

"I believe the meeting with undergrads is supposed to involve fewer undergrads for a more personal meeting with the candidates."

Who was invited? Only TAs like you and Michael Ball? That's not representative of the undergraduates...

Andrew is staff and not taking any classes, at least to my knowledge. He's definitely not being unfair to any of the candidates. :)

But in any case, usually you know your advisor before coming to Berkeley and even before applying.
oh, I thought Andrew (who used to be my TA) became a grad student after graduating. When did he become staff and what's his role in the EECS department? Is he working with Chris Hunn to do advising?
I don't think Andrew needs to be brought into this.

I don't mean to offend anyone, but I find these statements honestly a bit rude. Andrew is not a grad student; he's the course manager for 61A and 61B. He's been helping us a lot at 61B, and he is great to work with.

Also, Prof. Dan Garcia is the one who specifically asked Andrew to help with organizing the meetings. It's not like Andrew's unilaterally making decisions. He's just organizing the undergrads together by doing things like scheduling times, booking rooms, and taking notes. Here is a quote from Prof. Garcia's email:

Andrew — can you take the lead on gathering undergrad names, make sure we fill the rooms, and take the lead to summarize student comments?

So please don't say these sorts of things. If you have concerns, I suggest taking them privately to Prof. Garcia or other faculty involved in the interview process. These sorts of statements are hurtful, and I think the CS community should remain open and grateful to someone who really puts a lot of effort into making lower-div classes a better experience for the many incoming students.

Sarah, I was bringing up a valid concern. A grad student should not be evaluating professor candidates because of the inherent conflict of interest.

My feedback was based on an error. Andrew is staff, not a grad student. So my feedback DOES NOT apply, and it's totally fine that Andrew's doing this. I'm grateful to Andrew for taking on this task.

He was my TA several years ago, and I admired his passion for teaching (and his cookies!). I think he's a great teacher and a great person.

Why is honest feedback always met with accusations of rudeness? That just makes people less willing to speak up when they see something they think might be wrong. That's NOT what the CS community should be encouraging.
Sorry about that. It appears that I misinterpreted the tone of the three previous posts. It's often hard to tell with writing. Sorry! >_< And I haven't tried his cookies yet. Must bug him!

That's okay! :)

Andrew's cookies are amazing! You definitely have to try them at least once! :)

Also, on the note about Grads. The grad students generally have more say in interviewing than undergrads do, and for many years have been involved in reviewing candidates. (I've heard rumors that past grads have had 'veto' votes on candidates but I'm not sure how true that is.)

Where did you hear the grad rumor from? I don't think they would have that much power.

I thought all hiring decisions were made only by the department chair and tenured professors and that undergrads and grads just provide feedback on whether they liked the candidates.

Yes, but at least last year, it definitely sounded like the grads had more power.  (However, I got the impression that some combination of faculty and staff were the ones who made the decision, not the grads.)

Yep, in terms of official power, it's definitely faculty, and probably up to the chair. 

The point was more that, if grads really didn't like someone, the faculty would take it very seriously. (This is pretty understandable, because it would suck to have a PhD advisor with whom you couldn't work. And in terms of timelines, the grad students sometimes spend 10 years here, so it does make sense that someone listen to them.)
Why is Andrew Huang, a first-year grad student, evaluating the candidates? That seems unseemly because one of them could be his advisor next year.

history.content:
From Hilfinger's CS164 lecture slides:
Josh Hug interviewing today and Tuesday: – Vision Seminar: Mon 04:30–05:30 in 380 Soda – Undergrads: Tues 09:30–10:15am in 380 Soda – Mock Class: Tues 10:30-11:30am in 380 Soda – Grads: Tues 03:00–03:45pm in 315 Soda
Hilfinger said in addition to Josh Hug, a Lecturer 18 who is hired from semester to semester or year to year, there are two other candidates who will be interviewing for a Lecturer PSOE position in the upcoming months. I didn't see any announcements about this anywhere except from Hilfinger. Shouldn't stuff like this be announced in the EECS/CS mailing lists and on the EECS website?
history.subject: Three candidates interviewing for a Lecturer PSOE position; announcements please?
